Hey Product Hunt! üëã

I'm on the marketing team at Typeless, and I'm thrilled to finally share what we've been working on!

From a marketing perspective, here's why Typeless is different:

The Core Message:

"The keyboard was a mistake" - this isn't just a tagline. It's a fundamental truth about how we work. We think at 150 words per minute but type at 40. That gap is where productivity dies.

Our Positioning:

We're not selling "another dictation tool." We're selling a paradigm shift: Speak, don't type. üöÄ

Key Differentiators We're Highlighting:

1. Intelligence, Not Just Transcription

  • No filler words, no repetition - your thoughts come out clear

  • Writes what you meant to say, not just what you said

  • This is the message that resonates most in user testing

2. Context Awareness

Most dictation tools are one-size-fits-all. Typeless adapts:

  • Casual tone in chat apps

  • Professional tone in email

  • Concise tone in docs

This is a huge unlock for professional users who've been burned by "robotic" dictation before.

3. Real-World Usability

Whisper mode is our answer to "I can't use voice dictation in public." We're designing for actual work environments, not ideal conditions.

The Two New Superpowers:

‚úçÔ∏è Writing Assistance - Select text ‚Üí speak commands like "make this professional" or "fix grammar"

üìñ Reading Assistance - Select text ‚Üí speak queries like "summarize this" or "find action items"

These features extend Typeless beyond input - now it's your AI writing partner for everything.

Platform Availability:

We've launched on both Windows and Mac to reach the broadest audience of desktop professionals.

What We're Hearing from Early Users:

  • "Finally, dictation that doesn't embarrass me"

  • "I can write emails 3x faster"

  • "Whisper mode is a game-changer for open offices"

I'd love your feedback on:

  • Does "the keyboard was a mistake" resonate with you?

  • What would make you switch from typing to voice?

  • Which use case excites you most - emails, docs, notes, or something else?

Your feedback helps us refine our messaging and build what users actually need. Thanks for the support! üôè

today we're announcing Zo. 

when we came up with the idea ‚Äì giving everyone a personal server, powered by AI ‚Äì it sounded crazy. 

but now, even my mom has a server of her own.

and it's making her life better.

she thinks of Zo as her personal assistant. she texts it to manage her busy schedule, using all the context from her notes and files. she no longer needs me for tech support

she also uses Zo as her intelligent workspace ‚Äì she asks it to organize her files, edit documents, and do deep research. 

with Zo's help, she can run code from her graduate students and explore the data herself.

Zo has given my mom a real feeling of agency ‚Äì she can do so much more with her computer.

we want everyone to have that same feeling. we want people to fall in love with making stuff for themselves. 

in the future we're building, we'll own our data, craft our own tools, and create personal APIs. 

owning an intelligent cloud computer will be just like owning a smartphone.

A no-code workflow builder we‚Äôd spent months crafting.

Delete the product. Rebuild from zero. Forget everything except the user‚Äôs actual life.

No more drag-and-drop boxes.
No more flowcharts.
No more turning users into engineers.

Just one idea:
What if you could run your entire workday by texting one message?

So we rebuilt everything around WhatsApp ‚Äî the most frictionless interface on earth.

Ten days after launch:

112 users
16 paying customers ($378 in MRR)
33% week-over-week growth
$0 CAC

And students (who we didn‚Äôt even design for) became 33% of our usage because they were drowning in tasks more than anyone.

The market didn‚Äôt just ‚Äúaccept‚Äù the change ‚Äî it dragged us toward it.

What Airstitch actually does?

‚ÄúCheck my email for anything urgent and schedule what matters.‚Äù
‚ÄúLook at my Canvas deadlines and add everything to Calendar.‚Äù
‚ÄúWhen a client emails, open a Linear ticket and notify Slack.‚Äù
‚ÄúFind the pricing doc from last week in Drive.‚Äù

No setup.
No learning curve.
No ‚Äúbuilding automations.‚Äù
Just‚Ä¶ relief.

A rejection can be the most accurate roadmap.
People want clarity, not control.
Mental load is a bigger problem than automation.

üöÄ We‚Äôre excited to launch Spine Canvas!


Spine AI is an infinite thinking and creation canvas powered by 300+ AI models. Every model becomes a block ‚Äî chat, text, lists, deep research, image generation, slide generation, app generation across models like Gemini 3, and more. You can pass context between blocks, branch ideas, and run them in parallel.

Instead of juggling Google Docs, Notion, tabs of different LLMs, and scattered design tools, you get one workspace where thinking ‚Üí exploration ‚Üí creation happens seamlessly.

Also here are some power user shortcuts and tips:

  1. Copy paste public ChatGPT, Gemini or Grok links into the canvas and watch the ‚ú®

  2. Use https://app.getspine.ai/new for a new canvas

  3. Double click anywhere on the canvas to add a new block

  4. Drag and drop files anywhere directly onto the canvas

As an engineer, I mostly use Spine Canvas just as a regular user who often doesn‚Äôt know the exact steps to start with.

For open-ended tasks‚Äîwriting blogs, brainstorming engineering problems, exploring the best trading algos, or even doing fun stuff like making a comic-style breakdown of the upcoming Marvel movie Doomsday‚Äî Spine Canvas has become my default place to think. Instead of bouncing between tabs and search results, I just drop everything onto a canvas and let it pull in what I need, so I can work through it all in one place. It makes research-heavy work feel a lot less tiring and a lot more structured.

What I love most is how context works here. Because it‚Äôs a canvas and not just a linear chat, I can throw in notes, links, docs, ideas‚Äîwhatever‚Äîand different blocks can share and reuse that context. I don‚Äôt have to worry about the AI forgetting what we were doing; the canvas itself is the memory.

On top of that, from the same space I can generate high-quality images, spin up presentations, or even build some great apps on the go. As someone helping build it, it‚Äôs been really fun to see how much it already improves my own workflow, and I‚Äôm genuinely excited to see where we take Spine Canvas next.

As an engineer on the team, what excites me most about Spine Canvas is how well it supports real technical workflows. Architecture work is never linear you‚Äôre evaluating patterns, exploring alternative system designs, comparing models, and keeping multiple layers of context (requirements, constraints, docs, traces) aligned.

Canvas finally gives me a visual workspace to map architectures, branch into different implementation paths, test reasoning across models, and link research, specs, and diagrams together. Being able to run parallel flows and re-use context across blocks has genuinely improved how I design and iterate on systems.


Can‚Äôt wait to see how other engineers use it for architecture, research, and multi-model workflows. üöÄ

I built SixtySec because I struggled to journal consistently... even though I knew how powerful it could be. Most journaling apps felt overwhelming, time-consuming, or didn‚Äôt truly respect privacy. I wanted something simple enough to use every day, but thoughtful enough to actually help with clarity and emotional awareness.

Along the way, I leaned heavily into privacy-first design, multimedia capture (text, voice, video), and making reflection feel supportive not analytical or clinical.

body:
Hi Product Hunt,

I‚Äôm Craig, the founder of Calibrate.

I built Calibrate when I was in the middle of struggling with anxiety, panic attacks and agoraphobia. I was tired of opening anxiety apps (or most support) during a moment of high stress, only to be greeted by a cartoon character or a guilt trip about "breaking my streak." When you are in a state of panic, you don't need gamification‚Äîyou need physiological regulation.

We designed Calibrate to be the no fluff app that I always wished I had. We stripped away the fluff to focus on speed, data, and neuroscience.

How Calibrate is different:

ü§ñ The AI is a Clinical Analyst, not a Chatbot: It doesn't just chat; it analyzes your logs. If your anxiety spikes every Tuesday at 2 PM, the AI uses your habit data to help you understand why, and suggests interventions based on your history.

ü´Ä Haptics over Audio: We lean heavily on the iPhone‚Äôs Taptic Engine. During a panic attack, focusing on a physical vibration pattern is often more grounding than listening to a voice recording.

üìä Data over "Vibes": We show you what is working. Our "Community Efficacy" feature aggregates anonymous data to show you which techniques are statistically reducing anxiety for others in real-time.

Calibrate is for the skeptics, the data-lovers, and anyone who wants support without the "woo-woo."

I‚Äôd love to hear your thoughts on our AI Analyst‚Äîwe are working hard to make it feel like a supportive tool rather than a generic bot.

Thanks for checking us out.

body:
What inspired you to build this?

Got laid off 3 months before my baby was born. Instead of panicking, I took a sabbatical and decided to build something useful.

What problem were you trying to solve?
Every baby tracker I tried felt like homework. Too many fields, guilt-inducing streaks, dashboards full of data I never asked for. I just wanted to log things fast and know when my baby would need sleep next without the app making me feel like a bad parent.

How did your approach evolve?
Started with just logging. Then I noticed I was always guessing  when was the last feed, when I changed his diaper or when he needs to take a nap. So I built a nap prediction algorithm based on pediatric sleep science (Exponential Weighted Adaptive Learning) that learns from your actual logs. Added partner sync because my wife and I kept asking each other "did you feed her?" Added AI chat for those 3am panic moments. Every feature came from a real problem

body:
The idea came from seeing what happens when a person meets with an accident and is taken to the hospital with no family member around. In such situations, doctors have no way of knowing the patient‚Äôs medical history, past surgeries, allergies, or ongoing treatments. This lack of information can delay proper treatment and even put the patient‚Äôs life at risk. That‚Äôs when the idea of creating a Heal ID came up ‚Äî a digital card that stores a patient‚Äôs medical history and can be accessed instantly by hospitals. The goal was to make sure no patient becomes ‚Äúunknown‚Äù in an emergency again.

We are solving the problem of missing medical records, delayed treatment, and poor coordination between hospitals. Patients often lose reports or forget details about past illnesses. With the Heal ID digital card, all medical history is stored in one place and linked with Aadhaar for accurate identification. Doctors can quickly view a patient‚Äôs past history, which helps avoid wrong medication, repeated tests, and confusion during emergencies. It also makes healthcare smoother, faster, and more reliable for both doctors and patients.

In the beginning, the focus was mainly on building a system to store health records online. Later, we realized that just having data online wasn‚Äôt enough ‚Äî it had to be easy to access during emergencies. That‚Äôs when the idea of a Heal ID digital card came in. We also added Aadhaar linking to make sure records belong to the right person. Over time, our approach changed from creating a simple database to building a complete healthcare identity system that doctors can actually use in real situations.

Hi everyone! üëã
I built ScreenBreak because traditional app blockers never worked well for me. Hard blocks felt too rigid ‚Äî either I locked myself out completely, or I tapped Ignore Limit and kept scrolling. There was no middle ground.

But in real life, we do sometimes need to open addictive apps ‚Äî to search something, reply to someone, check updates. The problem isn‚Äôt the intentional use; it‚Äôs the unconscious, endless scrolling that follows. Soft blocking creates a balance: you can still access the app when needed, but you must put in effort, which naturally filters out mindless usage.

After nearly a year of iteration, I designed multiple flexible ways for ScreenBreak to activate:
- Schedule Block ‚Äì block during certain hours
- App Launch Limit ‚Äì block after too many opens
- Usage Budget Limit ‚Äì block after hitting time caps (daily or hourly)

When a block triggers, you must complete a quick challenge ‚Äî tapping fast, shaking your phone, drawing a circle, etc. Win for a short access window; fail, and the urge usually fades.

I‚Äôd love your feedback on challenge design and which blocking rules fit your habits best. Thanks for checking it out! üöÄ

This is a very niche product. It‚Äôs built for medtech founders, RA/QA teams, and regulatory consultants who live in the world of 510(k)s, product codes, predicates, guidance docs, test plans, and eSTAR. If that sounds like another planet, that‚Äôs totally okay ‚Äì Cruxi is probably not meant for you üôÇ

We started building Cruxi after seeing how painful and expensive 510(k) work is for small teams. You‚Äôre trying to build a device, raise money, and learn FDA language at the same time ‚Äì then you hit classification, predicates, testing requirements, and eSTAR formatting, and everything either slows down for months or gets outsourced for five figures.

Cruxi tries to turn that chaos into something structured and actionable:

classify your device and map it to the right regulation/product code

surface relevant predicates, guidance, and safety data

outline likely testing and documentation expectations

draft eSTAR-ready sections you can review with your RA/QA team or consultant

The first versions were basically ‚Äúsmart search‚Äù over FDA data. We quickly realized no one wanted yet another search box ‚Äì they wanted a chain of agents that actually do the work: read the regulations, score fit, propose predicates, and turn that into a concrete plan and draft content.

Cruxi is not a replacement for experienced regulatory professionals. It‚Äôs meant to make their work (and their clients‚Äô lives) less painful and more predictable, especially for teams without big RA budgets.

Because this is so specialized, we really appreciate kind, constructive feedback from people who work in:

medtech / digital health

regulatory affairs / quality

consulting around FDA submissions

If this isn‚Äôt your domain, feel free to just be curious or ask questions rather than judge it by consumer-product standards. And if you are in this space, we‚Äôd love to hear what would make Cruxi genuinely useful in your day-to-day work. üíô

I built Steply because I wanted a clearer, more motivating way to understand my walking habits. I walk a lot every day, and I realized how helpful it would be to see my patterns, progress, and routines in a more visual and meaningful way.

I hope Steply helps you stay active, feel better, and enjoy your daily walks even more ‚Äî just like it helped me.
Happy to answer questions and hear your feedback!

I built Align because I was tired of knowing exactly what to do to change my life, I‚Äôd read every book and watched every video, but I couldn't stay consistent. I realized the problem wasn't laziness because after watching videos from so many different many manifestation gurus I figured it was identity, something that all of them are talking about, just in a a little different way. They'd say my subconscious was rejecting my new goals because they didn't match my old self-image.

I also don't like the half products that the market is full of, just simple mood tracker (okay I documented my mood and you told me not to worry but what now) or habit trackers (I'm here because I can't stay consistent, but this documenting of what I do in a day is just another task I will probably procrastinate on) and then also the manifestation courses that all try to teach you something but fail at being practical and also teach it as it's magic. 

So I built this app make the user come back every day because that is simply the only thing they have to do to have the higher chances of reaching their dream life. Might sound like I'm selling air (lol) but every feature has its so here they are:

- detailed big quiz (your dream life and perfect persona) - you read it every day to remind yourself what you're living for
- daily quizzes - specifically made questions to start your day in the right frequency and review it to improve the next day
- vision board (better than you make it at home) - pictures with specific text sections to reinforce your new identity
- journal feature (but better!!) - in one sections you write your throughout your day, then you have An Alchemist, AI that will on press of a button rewrite your day in a perfect version so you can slowly pick up the patterns and soon live as your perfect identity
- Frequencies AI - AI chat option with AI trained on the topic which also has memory of your journal and quiz entries so you can go deep with your problems with someone who won't judge you
- The Observer (my absolute favorite!) - an AI that you can trigger every 5 days, in that 5 days the AI collects all your journal and quiz entries, pairs them with context of who you want to be and gives you a very long and detailed report in 4 fields: Pattern Recognition (gives you a clear rundown on how did you do this week, I can't even tell you how well it writes it, on the site you can find some of responses it gave me), Identity Gap Analysis (tells you where your actions didn't relate with your goals/goal identity), 5 Day Protocol (a personalized protocol until the next report), Trajectory Projection (tells you where you would be going if you repeated this same 5 days for a long time, gives you a good perspective)

All in all, I'm really proud of what I made and I'll be using it for myself if nobody else will :)

Let me know what you think of the idea, I'd like to hear multiple perspectives

Years ago, I made an app called Delightful‚Äîa gratitude journal where you'd write down three things you were grateful for each day. The user feedback taught me something: gratitude practice genuinely helps people.

Hey all! Excited to launch Hone! I build this app to help my wife, who has been an Instagram creator for several years. She's often struggled with making consistent and engaging content, especially after the switch to Reels a few years back as the main type of content on IG. Happy to say, in the 3 month's she's been personally using it, she's literally doubled her audience and is growing a lot every day.

I'm hoping it helps others just as much. It turns out that the basics are what matters, but saying things like "make a stronger hook" or "make sure you're filling the frame" is not very useful... Hone gives you specific advice, examples and recommendations, and even a conversational assistant loaded up with tons of context about you to help make better content.

The main features are the video analysis and account analysis (Instagram only). They build on eachother, with video analysis getting ever better once it has an account analysis available. There is also a content idea generation tool which has been helpful for her.

Looking forwards to all the feedback I can get, thank you!

body:
**The Problem That Started It All**

It was 2 AM in Lagos, Nigeria. I had a client deadline in 6 hours.

I needed to merge 3 PDFs and compress them. Simple, right?

WRONG.

Every "free" PDF converter I tried:

‚ùå iLovePDF: "Sign up for free trial" (then $48/year)
‚ùå SmallPDF: 2 conversions per day limit (I needed 10)
‚ùå Sejda: Uploaded my files to their servers (client data!)
‚ùå Adobe: $15/month for basic features

I was furious. Why is something so simple so complicated?

**The Midnight Decision**

At 2:30 AM, instead of sleeping, I opened VS Code.

"Screw it. I'll build my own."

I knew it was possible to process PDFs entirely in the browser using:
- pdf-lib for PDF manipulation
- Canvas API for image conversion
- Client-side compression algorithms

No servers needed. No uploads. True privacy.

**72 Hours of Coding**

I didn't sleep much that weekend.

Built the core features:
‚úÖ Merge PDFs
‚úÖ Split PDFs
‚úÖ Compress PDFs
‚úÖ PDF to JPG/PNG
‚úÖ Image conversions

Tested it obsessively. Made sure it was FAST.

Deployed to Vercel. Free hosting. Perfect.

**Why I'm Sharing This**

I'm 22. From Nigeria. No venture capital. No team. Just me.

I built ConvertFlow because:

1. **Privacy matters** - Your files should never leave your device
2. **Free should mean FREE** - No hidden limits, no bait-and-switch
3. **Simple tools shouldn't require accounts** - Just use it and go

I've been hustling for 2 years trying to make something work. 

This is my shot.

If this helps even 100 people, it's worth it.

Try it: [https://convertflowcom.vercel.app/]

- Rick, Creator of ConvertFlow

Hey Product Hunt! üëã I'm Shai, maker of Ads.Bingo.

We built this because we were tired of the "Rent" model of online advertising. You pay Facebook/Google -> get views -> stop paying -> disappear. It felt like burning money on a fire that went out instantly.

So we asked: What if you could BUY a permanent slot on the internet?

Ads.Bingo is an experiment in Digital Real Estate:

Own, Don't Rent: You buy "Bingos" once, and you own a permanent share of our ad rotation. No subscriptions, no expiration.
Weighted RNG: Our algorithm spins the wheel every 15 seconds. The more Bingos you have, the higher your probability of being shown.
Deflationary Economy: We capped the supply at 20M Bingos. Early adopters get more Bingos for the same price as latecomers. (Decay rate of 0.05% per user).
We are live right now with a fresh pool. This means the first advertisers are getting massive visibility (nearly 100% share of voice) for a fraction of what it will cost later.

I'd love to hear your thoughts on this new ad model! üöÄ

The stage is yours. Warning: massive FOMO inside üòâ

body:
I built Blop AI after watching too many founders (including myself) ship products with UX issues that quietly kill conversions; broken checkout flows, inaccessible buttons, layout inconsistencies that users never mention but definitely notice.

The problem? Hiring a UX consultant takes weeks and costs thousands. Manual audits catch maybe 30% of issues. And by the time you realize something's wrong, you've already lost revenue.

Blop scans any website in seconds and finds the UX debt that's costing you money. But here's what makes it different from traditional audit tools:

It doesn't just tell you what's broken, it shows you the fix. AI-generated UI previews, concrete code suggestions, and even A/B test setups so you can validate what actually improves conversions.

Me and two of my friends built this during the Zero To Demo hackathon in Copenhagen, where we had 36 hours to go from idea to working product. The experience of watching real founders scan their sites live and immediately find issues they'd missed was both terrifying and incredibly validating.

Right now, Blop is in beta and free to use. I'm here today to get your honest feedback‚Äîscan your site, tell me what works, what doesn't, and what features would make this genuinely useful for your workflow.

Happy to answer any questions about our roadmap (A/B testing integration, Figma plugins, real-time monitoring) or just chat about design and UX/UI practices.

Thanks for checking it out!

I'm the solo developer behind Hypnotype.

I am not a podcaster or a video editor. I'm a dev who loves automating tedious workflows.

The Problem: I noticed that "Kinetic Typography" (those text animations that force you to read along) is the single best way to keep retention on audio content. But creating them? It‚Äôs a nightmare. Auto-Sync: You upload audio, it generates the video.

High Retention: It uses the "Dual Coding" principle (Audio + Visual Text) to keep viewers hooked.

Minimalist: No complex timelines. Just clean, bold aesthetics.

body:
Hey Product Hunt üëã
I‚Äôm the maker of picchat.ai. Thanks for checking it out.
The idea came from my own frustration with web-based AI image tools. They‚Äôre powerful, but they often feel slow, fragmented, and disposable. Generate an image, download it, upload it somewhere else, lose context, repeat. It didn‚Äôt feel like a creative tool, it felt like a form.

I wanted something that felt more like a real desktop studio: fast, focused, and iterative. A place where generating, editing, masking, resizing, and refining images all happen in one continuous flow, without juggling tabs or re-prompting from scratch.

That‚Äôs where Style Recipes came from. Instead of forcing people to become prompt engineers, I started encoding aesthetic intent (lighting, composition, realism, polish) into reusable presets. The goal was consistency and clarity, while still leaving room for control when you want it.

As I built it, the process evolved toward making AI feel less ‚Äúone-shot‚Äù and more conversational. Multi-turn edits, lightweight canvas tools, platform-specific resizing, and offline organization all came from trying to make the tool disappear and let the work stay front and center.

This launch is an early but complete version of that vision. I‚Äôm especially curious how creators, founders, and designers here use it in their real workflows and what feels magical versus clunky.

Happy to answer any questions, and genuinely grateful for any feedback

body:
A few months ago, I was building my first iOS app and wanted a clean, simple way to showcase it. Screenshots and screen recordings were easy, but turning them into smooth mockup animations took forever. Every transition needed tweaking, every video needed re-rendering ‚Äî it just wasn‚Äôt scalable.

I tried existing mockup tools, but they fell short in two areas that mattered most to me:
1. Animating multiple mockups at the same time
2. Showing different screenshots or videos at different moments in one animation
So I started building my own solution, just to speed up my workflow. That small idea slowly grew into iMockup.

With iMockup, you can:
1. Control multiple mockups on a single timeline
2. Swap images, videos, or UI states at precise moments
3. Build clean, polished animations in minutes instead of hours

Now I‚Äôm shipping it here to see if it helps others with the same problem.
If you create product demos, mobile apps, or UI showcases, I‚Äôd love to hear your feedback ‚Äî and what features you'd want next. Thanks for checking it out!

Hey Product Hunt! üëã

I built OG Image API because I got tired of manually creating Open Graph images for every blog post and landing page.

The existing solutions were either:
- Too complex (Vercel OG requires writing React components)
- Too expensive (Bannerbear starts at $49/mo)
- Too slow (Puppeteer-based solutions take seconds)

So I built a simple API: POST JSON, get a PNG back in ~65ms.

**What you get:**
- 10 professional templates (blog, product, profile, stats, events, etc.)
- Dark/light themes
- ~65ms generation time
- Free tier (25 images/month)

Try the live demo on the homepage - no signup needed!

Would love your feedback. What templates would you want to see next? üôè
